intro: Oliveriana guariniae, commonly known as the Guaraní olive, is a species of flowering plant native to South America, particularly Brazil. It belongs to the family Oleaceae, which includes other well-known genera like Olea and Fraxinus. The plant is characterized by its small, fragrant flowers and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. It typically grows in moist, shaded environments within tropical forests. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, Oliveriana guariniae is considered a rare and endangered species.
